title: [The role of protein kinase PAK1 in the regulation of estrogen-independent growth of breast cancer].
abstract: Osnovno? zadache? nastoiashche? raboty iavilos' issledovanie vnutrikletochnykh signal'nykh pute?, otvetstvennykh za razvitie gormonal'no? rezistentnosti i podderzhanie avtonomnogo rosta kletok raka molochno? zhelezy, v chastnosti – izuchenie roli RAK1 (r21-activated kinase 1), odnogo iz kliuchevykh mitogennykh signal'nykh belkov, v razvitii rezistentnosti kletok k éstrogenam. Issledovaniia provedeny na kul'tiviruemykh in vitro kletkakh raka molochno? zhelezy: éstrogenzavisimo? linii MCF-7 i rezistentno? retseptor-negativno? linii HBL-100. My obnaruzhili, chto kletki rezistentno? linii HBL-100 otlichaiutsia vysokim soderzhaniem RAK1 i prodemonstrirovali aktivnoe uchastie RAK1 v podderzhanii éstrogennezavisimogo rosta opukholevykh kletok. Pri issledovanii nizhelezhashchikh signal'nykh pute?, aktiviruemykh RAK1, my ustanovili, chto v chislo éffektorov RAK1 vkhodit Snail1 – belok épitelial'no-mezenkhimal'nogo perekhoda, i pokazali ego znachenie v reguliatsii proliferatsii éstrogennezavisimykh kletok. V tselom, poluchennye rezul'taty demonstriruiut uchastie RAK1 i Snail1 v formirovanii éstrogennezavisimogo fenotipa kletok raka molochno? zhelezy i svidetel'stvuiut o vozmozhnosti ispol'zovaniia étikh belkov v kachestve markerov razvitiia gormonal'no? rezistentnosti opukhole? molochno? zhelezy.The main goal of this work was to study the intracellular signaling pathways responsible for the development of hormone resistance and maintaining the autonomous growth of breast cancer cells. In particular, the role of PAK1 (p21-activated kinase 1), the key mitogenic signaling protein, in the development of cell resistance to estrogens was analyzed. In vitro studies were performed on cultured breast cancer cell lines: estrogen-dependent estrogen receptor (ER)-positive MCF-7 cells and estrogen-resistant ER-negative HBL-100 cells. We found that the resistant HBL-100 cells were characterized by a higher level of PAK1 and demonstrated PAK1 involvement in the maintaining of estrogen-independent cell growth. We have also shown PAK1 ability to up-regulate Snail1, one of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition proteins, and obtained experimental evidence for Snail1 importance in the regulation of cell proliferation. In general, the results obtained in this study demonstrate involvement of PAK1 and Snail1 in the formation of estrogen-independent phenotype of breast cancer cells showing the potential role of both proteins as markers of hormone resistance of breast tumors.
